sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The &app; application enables you to record and play waveform (.wav) sound files.

sect1.title: Getting Started
sect1.para: You can start &app; in the following ways:

listitem.para: Choose Sound & VideoSound Recorder
Type gnome-sound-recorder, then press Return.

sect1.para: When you start &app;, the following window is displayed.

textobject.phrase: Shows &app; main window. Contains menubar, toolbar, progress bar, and statusbar.

sect2.title: To Start a New Recording
sect2.para: To start a new recording session, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Click New on the toolbar.
To start recording, click Record on the toolbar.
To stop recording, click Stop on the toolbar.
To play back the recording, click Play on the toolbar.
To save the recording, choose FileSave As, then type a name for the sound file.

sect2.title: To Play a Sound File
sect2.para: To play a sound file, choose FileOpen. Select a sound file in the Select a sound file dialog, then click OK. &app; displays the duration of the file in minutes and seconds to the right of the progress bar. To play the file, click Play. The progress indicator moves along the progress bar as the sound file is playing.

sect2.title: To Add an Echo to a Sound File
sect2.para: To add an echo to a sound file, open the sound file, then choose EditEffects EchoAdd echo.

sect2.title: To Undo Changes to a Sound File
sect2.para: To undo all of the changes that you made to a sound file since you last saved the file, choose EditUndo All.

sect1.title: Preferences
sect1.para:
To configure &app;, choose
Edit Preferences . The &app; Preferences dialog contains the following tabbed sections:

listitem.para: Use this spin box to specify the time in minutes after which &app; stops recording if there is no interaction from the user.
Default: 2 minutes.
Select this option to stop recordings when &app; reaches the timeout limit specified in the Recording timeout spin box.
Default: selected.

term.guilabel: Open Save dialog when recording is finished

listitem.para: Select this option to automatically open the Save sound file dialog when &app; finishes a recording.
Default: unselected.

term.guilabel: Show warning message if size (MB) of sample becomes bigger than

listitem.para: Select this option to display a warning message if the size of the sound file that you are recording exceeds 100 MB. Use the spin box to modify the file size at which you want to display a warning.
Default: selected, 100 MB.

term.guilabel: Stop recording if size (MB) of sample becomes bigger than

listitem.para: Select this option to stop the recording if the size of the sound file exceeds 200 MB. Use the spin box to modify the file size at which you want to stop recording.
Default: unselected, 200 MB.
Select one of the following options to determine how &app; plays sound files:
Select this option to play the sound file once.
Select this option to play the sound file indefinitely until you click Stop or quit the application.
Select this option to play the sound file the number of the times that is specified in the spin box. Use the spin box to modify the number of times &app; plays the file.
Default: Number of times, 2.

Use this field to specify the location of the sox application. &app; uses sox to play back recordings. To determine the location of sox, type which sox at a command line. To apply a change to the field, click Apply.
Default: depends on your operating system.
Use this field to specify the directory in which to temporarily save sound files while &app; is recording the files. To apply a change to the field, click Apply.
Default: depends on your operating system.

sect2.title: Sound
sect2.para: The preferences that you select in this tabbed section only apply to new sound files that you create.

listitem.para: Select one of the following options to determine the number of bits per sample in the sound files:
Select this option to save the sound files using 8-bit pulse code modulation (PCM).
Select this option to save the sound files using 16-bit PCM.
Default: 8-bit PCM.
Use this field to specify the number of samples per second.
Default: 11025.
Select one of the following options to determine whether the sound file is mono or stereo:
Select this option to save the sound files in monophonic format.
Select this option to save the sound files in stereophonic format. This format results in a larger sound file.
Default: Stereo.
